subject: Tiny Improvements to Quikscript
msgSnippet: In the past couple of weeks I have posted (in the Files section) several poems transcribed into Senior Quikscript.  In transcribing them, I have used a couple
messageBody:
In the past couple of weeks I have posted (in the Files section) several poems transcribed into Senior Quikscript.  In transcribing them, I have used a couple of minor modifications/additions to Senior that I want to discuss here, and argue for their merits.  (These changes don't apply to Junior Quikscript because they are related to cursive writing and avoidance of penlifts in Senior).

The most commonly used modification relates to Letter 24, the symbol for the "L" sound.  Consider how to write the word "flight" in Senior using the regular letter L:  a letter "F", penlift, a letter "L", penlift, a Letter 31 ("my"), and the final "T".  Penlifts galore!  Now imagine an additional form for the letter "L" which is formed by reflecting the original "L" horizontally so that the new form starts on the upper parallel and ends on the lower parallel instead of vice versa like the original "L".  Now, using this alternate "L", writing "flight" becomes:  a letter "F", NO penlift, an alternate letter "L", NO penlift, a Letter 31 ("my"), and the final "T".  As with the alternate letter "N" which can be "upside down" or right-side up, the alternate "L" would be called into service only when needed for ease of connected, penlift-avoiding writing.  I don't think this "new" letter can be confused with any existing letter forms.  It's easily-recognizable as a "backwards" L.

Another less-often needed similar addition would allow the Letter 21 ("NG") to be written both right-side up and "upside down", like its cousin the letter "N", useful in avoiding a penlift in writing the word "leasing", since it would consist of an "L", a Letter 27 ("even") which ends on the writing line so the following letter "S" would be written from bottom to top (avoiding a penlift after the Letter 27), and now the pen is at tall-letter height and the final Letter 21 needs to be written (the vowel Letter 26 being elided, as discussed on the bottom of page 18 of the Manual).....requiring a big penlift to come down to the writing line to begin the final letter.  But if Letter 21 ("NG") could be written "upside down", no penlift would be required.  Again, it's hard to imagine how an "upside down" Letter 21 would not easily and immediately be recognized as such.

Since avoiding penlifts is a high priority in Senior, it seems to me that these are useful additions.


                     Dave Slayton
